#Text=Francis Moore ( geographer )
#Text=Francis Moore ( baptized 1708 , died in or after 1756 ) was a British travel writer of the eighteenth century .
#Text=Moore was born in Worcester , England , but few details are known about his early life .
#Text=He came into prominence after publishing Travels into the Inland Parts of Africa in 1738 .
#Text=The abolitionist Thomas Clarkson attributed his commitment to the anti-slavery cause to reading the few experts on Africa of the time , including Moore . [ 1 ] [ 2 ]
#Text=Account of Africa
#Text=Moore was appointed a writer ( i.e. , clerk ) by the Royal African Company in 1730 and sailed for the company ’s Gambia River entrepôt on July of that year .
#Text=He left the region in April 1735 after also serving as a factor ( agent ) for the company .

#Text=Moore was one of the first Englishmen to travel into the interior of Africa , serving in and visiting numerous towns and trading posts along the Gambia River from its mouth to the Guinea Highlands , hundreds of miles inland .
#Text=Moore ’s observations were published as Travels Into the Interior Parts of Africa .

#Text=The short account describes in rich detail the physical and cultural geography of the region before the intensification of the Atlantic slave trade and the resulting depopulation and economic disintegration .
#Text=Moore ’s work and Richard Jobson ’s The Golden Trade were the only detailed accounts of Gambia before the colonial period . [ 3 ]

#Text=Excerpts from Travels Into the Interior Parts of Africa were published in several subsequent volumes on exploration and the slave trade , including Samuel Johnson et al. , The World Displayed ( 1740 ) ; Thomas Astley ’ s A New General Collection of Voyages and Travels ( 1745 ) ; and Elizabeth Donnan ’s Documents Illustrative of the Slave Trade to America ( 1931 ) . [ 4 ]
#Text=Association with Job ben
#Text=Solomon
#Text=Moore related the saga of Job ben Solomon , also known as Ayuba Suleiman Diallo , in Travels Into the Interior Parts of Africa .
#Text=Job was an African aristocrat taken by slavers in 1730 in an incident recorded by Moore .
#Text=He was enslaved in Maryland until 1733 , when he was sent to England after James Oglethorpe received a letter from him and purchased his freedom .
#Text=After becoming well-known and respected in London society , Job returned to the Gambia , where he became re-acquainted with Moore . [ 5 ]
#Text=Account of the Georgia Colony
#Text=Moore sailed to the Province of Georgia on November , 1735 , only four months after returning to England from Gambia , with James Oglethorpe and over 200 colonists .
#Text=It was a return trip for Oglethorpe , who had founded the colony in February 1733 .
#Text=Among those also on the voyage were newly ordained brothers John Wesley and Charles Wesley . [ 6 ] [ 7 ]
#Text=Moore served as Oglethorpe 's secretary , and as storekeeper at Fort Frederica on the southern frontier of the Georgia colony .
#Text=He served in the colony until 1743 , visiting his homeland once before permanently returning to England the same year as Oglethorpe . [ 8 ]
#Text=Moore ’s early observations in the colony were published under the title A Voyage to Georgia .
#Text=The account contains some of the most detailed information available on the Oglethorpe Plan and its implementation .

#Text=Moore ’s account of Georgia is silent on Oglethorpe ’s emerging anti-slavery position ; however it seems likely that the two men discussed Africa and the slave trade at length , and this may have informed the latter ’s views . [ 9 ]
